The game is also very inclusive as it offers an assistance mode that slows down the pace a bit for those who want to have a little more laid-back playthrough or if you need some help to get the feel of the controls and difficulty as you start at the beginning. But once you get going, those training wheels quickly fall off as you want to go faster and faster!!!

Solid action game. Environment design is incredible and probably the best part of the experience. The action gameplay is placed front and centre, and while it is fun, it isn't particularly deep. Enemies are not intelligent with their aiming, only shooting at your current location, so as long as you're constantly moving you won't get hit. Traversal fairs little better - the protagonist will magnetise to walls and rails, and grapple points only require a single button click. The room for skill expression is low. About the most complex movement option is chaining a dash into a slide for a quick burst of speed. 

With enemies dying in one hit, the strategy comes not from the actual killing of them but the routing between them, dodging and occasionally deflecting projectiles as they come. This necessitates an understanding of the level layout, and therefore a lot of trial and error is required, and consequently a lot of death. Checkpoints are very generously placed to compensate for this, which leads to low stakes gameplay where death is more or less considered a part of the experience - unfortunately further reducing the potential for skill expression. 

This all leads to gameplay having a sort of mindless quality, being fairly enjoyable but not truly engaging. I've seen the game be described as [i] difficult [/i], and I have to strongly disagree. Its only [i] difficult [/i] if by difficult you mean you die a lot. Which you do. But despite that, the game rarely feels [i] challenging [/i], due to its shallow mechanics.

The developers wisely made restarting as quick and painless as possible - after dying, one button press instantaneously starts you at the last checkpoint with you in full control. Any kind of load screen could have completely killed the game's momentum and I'm VERY glad they ensured this didn't happen. It speaks to a level of awareness of the user experience that they clearly had when putting the game together. Similarly, the story is delivered not through gameplay-interrupting cutscenes, which would be detrimental to a game with such a heavy emphasis on fast paced action, instead opting to deliver exposition through voiceovers that play during levels. 

The writing is not exactly a masterclass but it gives context to the world and is enjoyable enough to follow. The music is alright - falls into the same category as DOOM or Dark Souls in my eyes, in the sense that the tracks sort of blend into one while playing and I certainly wouldn't listen to them outside of the game - but nevertheless they convey the right atmosphere.

Overall its a fun game, but don't expect anything too deep.

Awesome fast paced action gameplay.  An underrated gem of a game, absolutely worth playing if you like Cyberpunk themes or Sci-Fi action games.  The choice to minimise ranged weapons (mostly unlocking near the end of the game besides temporary powerups) forces the player to think quickly deciding the best approach moment to moment in a fluid and surprisingly easy to learn parkour/melee combat system.

Taking design cues from games like Half Life, there's very little in the way of HUD making for a very immerisive combat experience.  Using in world design elements like lighting and signage makes navigating the cyberpunk world of Ghostrunner feel like second nature.  

A compelling story drives the action forward at a blistering pace, but despite the fact that you're whipping through levels at speed every area feels unique and adds to the story and world you're exploring.  

The story is fully voice acted and the actors do a great job delivering the material.  Most of the story told through conversations between the Ghostrunner and other characters via radio (or whatever cyber tech equivalent) which you won't be stuck watching cutscenes in between the action.

The majority of the gameplay consists of platforming and melee combat, you'll often need to earn enemies locations and a good route through an area before you can progress.  This is broken up with some light puzzle elements and some exciting platforming challenge sections which are consistently fun throughout the game providing some opportunities for the slower paces story sections and giving the player some breathing room to learn and master the various powerups and special abilities as they unlock. 

This isn't what I'd call an easy game, but the developers have done a great job of balancing the difficulty with generous checkpoints, and the gradual difficulty curve means you get a great sense of accomplishment from progressing towards the end of the game.  Replayability wise there's a bunch of secrets to discover that much like Doom will usually be missed on a first playthrough but once you learn how to spot them you'll have a lot of fun discovering new cosmetics and lore items hidden throughout the  maps.  

A masterclass in traditional linear game designg taking great elements from classic games and combing them in a way that feels totally unique and yet familiar with a high level of polish that gives some modern AAA titles a run for their money.

Overall it's easy to recommend Ghostrunner just for it's gameplay but the story and visuals take the game to another level that is increasingly rare for new games.

[b]Summary:[/b]  This is barely a recommend; the game has just enough going for it to overcome its flaws.  It is definitely not for everyone.  If you want a parkour game instead of a bullet dodger then you will be severely disappointed.
 [hr]

[b]Pros[/b]
- It is a gorgeous game, despite some sacrifices to make it so.  Probably due to the ray-tracing more than anything.  It's drenched in neon, which entertains me to no end as an 80s arcade rat.  The ray tracing can be disabled because the game moves so fast you won't have much time to appreciate the visuals the vast majority of the time you're playing it.  Regardless, the visuals are very much a high point for Ghostrunner.
- Movement is very satisfying, with level design that offers visual cues to help guide you.  This is similar to Mirror's Edge though not quite as blatantly implemented.  The default controls can be a bit much for the left hand so you may want to re-bind a few controls to your mouse (such as the air dodging).  No idea how this would play with a controller.
- When everything goes right there is a genuine exhilaration in the gameplay experience.  It's fast, stylish, gory, and rewarding to nail an area.  You are always at a disadvantage in the game and hence overcoming every area feels like a significant accomplishment.

[b]Cons[/b]
- Running on a 3070 the game barely cracks 30fps at 4K, which basically makes it an impossible slideshow.  DLSS set to Performance was required to get this game running at a sometimes-stable 60fps.  Shader caching causes significant hitching whenever you encounter something new.  It's usually best to just run around and die a couple times to try get all the area shaders cached.
- The game is a lot like Boshy, Super Meat Boy, or similar games where you're expected to die from a single hit countless times.  This isn't necessarily a con for everyone, but it is frustrating to me because of the implementation. Basically every area starts with you moving somewhere to get a bearing on your surroundings only to eat a random shot from an enemy.  
- Needing to take blind deaths until you can find all your enemies and make a game plan to get through an area really drags down the experience.  A minimap shows enemies as red dots, but no walls, verticality, etc. so it is of minimal use.

[b]Ugly[/b]
- The best way I can describe Ghostrunner is that it is the literal videogame equivalent of bringing a knife to a gun fight.  You have a sword, and everyone else has a gun which they can aim flawlessly and shoot without ever reloading.  You can't take their guns, and there's no stealth mechanics that would preclude using a noisy gun either. You apparently prefer taking the most difficult and dangerous tactic for the sole purpose of using a sword.  There's no way using a gun is more difficult or complicated than running on walls and air dodging to get in melee stabby range.  I know, I know, it's just a videogame.  No matter how much I try I can't suspend disbelief that my character is this suicidal and/or stupid.
Ghostrunner is a meticulously crafted challenge that expects you to put on your cyberpunk ninja hat. If you don't already have one, this is a good step towards earning it.

I'm generally not a fan of high-skill games, as I feel I waste way too much time getting good enough to enjoy them. Ghostrunner gives players like me a lifeline in the form of very frequent checkpoints and immediate respawns. This allows you to really drill the techniques and reflexes needed for each encounter, while slowly increasing the difficulty curve.

There isn't much in terms of story, it's quite standard cyberpunk fare, but that's ok. The world is nicely designed to drive home the aesthetic, and the soundtrack with its bass synth-heavy lines works perfectly with it.

The game really shines in its combat though. Movement is fast and responsive, various upgrades keep things interesting, and level design almost feels like solving a puzzle in how you approach it. The fact that you die with a single hit makes for a challenge, but also makes it feel very rewarding to clear off a level without a single scratch. I haven't seen any other game nail the cyberpunk ninja feel quite so successfully.

Movement is good. Combat is...bad. Yeah that's the word. The combat is really really bad. The game essentially consists of fun but trivial platforming interspaced with frustrating trial & error combat sequences. The distance you need to be to kill an enemy is wildly inconsistent and the enemies can track through walls and instakill you. I’ve seen comparisons to Hotline Miami, but those are off the mark. In Hotline Miami the enemies actually react to the player in intuitive and consistent ways. The enemies in Ghostrunner stand around and are somewhat closer to platforming challenges than real combat. They function almost exactly like enemies in Mario games. I have died and tried the EXACT same thing and have succeeded, so there is extreme inconsistency with the ways enemies respond to you as well. The feeling of not knowing why you died is prevalent and this is very unsatisfying. When I succeed with a combat strategy one encounter and then fail in the next using the same tactics, I start to think that it is not my fault I died, but the fault of the game for having inconsistent mechanics. And that sucks the fun right out of any game. The one boss I faced before uninstalling this trash was named Tom and was a platforming memorization puzzle as if it were 1987. A truly dreadful boss.

Just get Ghostrunner 2. It resolves the endless issues present in this game and is significantly longer

Wallrunning in 1 is busted - You will randomly lose momentum or detach from walls. There's also an arbitrary "sweet spot" on walls and your jumps wont be full power unless you hit it. 

Ledge Grab - Camera required to be facing a specific (but arbitrary) direction/angle to land the grab. You will miss grabs while facing the ledge head-on, making full contact.

In short, most of your "failures" will have nothing to do with you. 

Lastly, combat isn't really combat. The enemies are more like "traps" in this game, which some people might actually prefer-- but if you're expecting enemies that chase/pursue you and have AI, this game does not offer that. The second game does.

It presents itself as very fluid and fast paced and at times both the combat and platforming can feel like that, but the mechanics simply don't work as well as I've seen in other parkour/fast paced games. Wall runs don't center you on the wall (making the next jump either too low or worse you are too high and start climbing on top of a wall you can't even stand on) and jumping between tight corridors often has you grabbing the wrong platform/wall; these very poorly designed mechanics make every fast paced run fall flat EVERY SINGLE TIME.

Combat also seems to be very inconsistent; the core gameplay is basically dying over and over again so you can learn from your mistakes or understand what you need to improve upon. Once you develop a rhythm and understand the placement of the enemies, you will naturally start following the same path to kill them all. Following the exact same path and using the exact same inputs will work like 85% of the time, the other 15% you will die and have no clue what it was that killed you; I have never played a game where the combat seems to be so inconsistent.

The platforming needs a lot of work despite older parkour games doing a much better job with the exact same mechanics, and the combat simply felt masochistic because of the crappy parkour elements and weird RNG instakills with enemies.

Maybe I'll come back to this game and play it more, but this game is simply inconsistent in platforming/combat and the times where I felt like a bad ass playing it were very short lived and ALWAYS fell flat because of poor mechanics; I don't feel like this is a "git gud" game, but more of like a puzzle game where you have figure out how to kill the enemies in the best path that provides the least chance for RNG killing you. 

My first time playing this game I played for about 2 hours, which usually means for me I will continue playing the game. At times I really was having fun and at times I felt like a bad ass; then using the same moves and inputs, I suddenly am getting killed instantly, I'm missing platforms, I'm moving fast and sliding through obstacles to leap off the edge of one and not know where I'm supposed to go, etc.

It presents itself as very fluid and fast paced and at times both the combat and platforming can feel like that, but the mechanics simply don't work as well as I've seen in other parkour/fast paced games. Wall runs don't center you on the wall (making the next jump either too low or worse you are too high and start climbing on top of a wall you can't even stand on) and jumping between tight corridors often has you grabbing the wrong platform/wall; these very poorly designed mechanics make every fast paced run fall flat EVERY SINGLE TIME.

Combat also seems to be very inconsistent; the core gameplay is basically dying over and over again so you can learn from your mistakes or understand what you need to improve upon. Once you develop a rhythm and understand the placement of the enemies, you will naturally start following the same path to kill them all. Following the exact same path and using the exact same inputs will work like 85% of the time, the other 15% you will die and have no clue what it was that killed you; I have never played a game where the combat seems to be so inconsistent.

The platforming needs a lot of work despite older parkour games doing a much better job with the exact same mechanics, and the combat simply felt masochistic because of the crappy parkour elements and weird RNG instakills with enemies.

Movement is good. Combat is...bad. Yeah that's the word. The combat is really really bad. The game essentially consists of fun but trivial platforming interspaced with frustrating trial & error combat sequences. The distance you need to be to kill an enemy is wildly inconsistent and the enemies can track through walls and instakill you. I’ve seen comparisons to Hotline Miami, but those are off the mark. In Hotline Miami the enemies actually react to the player in intuitive and consistent ways. The enemies in Ghostrunner stand around and are somewhat closer to platforming challenges than real combat. They function almost exactly like enemies in Mario games. I have died and tried the EXACT same thing and have succeeded, so there is extreme inconsistency with the ways enemies respond to you as well. The feeling of not knowing why you died is prevalent and this is very unsatisfying. When I succeed with a combat strategy one encounter and then fail in the next using the same tactics, I start to think that it is not my fault I died, but the fault of the game for having inconsistent mechanics. And that sucks the fun right out of any game. The one boss I faced before uninstalling this trash was named Tom and was a platforming memorization puzzle as if it were 1987. A truly dreadful boss.

- Inconsistent movement (the movement can send you off the map pretty easy)

- The 'easy' mode in this game is called the Assist Mode which gives you one more life and you can only select it via the select level menu which is a weird design choice. You have to start from this menu to have this mode on for the rest of the game.

I expected more from this game.
